thread.title_full: BlueScope workers back job cuts, pay freeze, to keep steelworks open | The Australian

author: The Australian
title: BlueScope workers back job cuts, pay freeze, to keep steelworks open |
text:
The three-year agreement, brokered between BlueScope and the Australian Workers’ Union, faced significant dissent but was endorsed this morning.
BlueScope Steel ( BSL ) flagged in August plans to cut 500 jobs from its 5000-strong workforce at Port Kembla, saying it needed $200 million in annual savings to maintain production in Australia.
Around 300 manufacturing jobs will be slashed through productivity reforms agreed to with the guidance of Fair Work Commission vice president Adam Hatcher.
A further 200 support and service positions will be eliminated, while unions have also agreed to suspend the Port Kembla wages bonus scheme.
BlueScope hailed the “game-changing approach”.
“The agreement is a significant and essential step to achieving the company’s $200 million cost reduction target,” BlueScope chief executive Paul O’Malley said.
The steel company has been fighting headwinds brought on by a plunge in steel prices amid a supply glut and soft demand from the global economy.
“I feel that the positive vote from employees today is a significant step-change improvement in our workplace -- one that will result in a more cost efficient and flexible steelworks,” Mr O’Malley said.
But he added: “We still have a lot of work to do in the coming weeks, as steel prices remain under pressure from the global steel glut.”
Wayne Phillips, the AWU chief at Port Kembla, said workers had agreed to sacrifices in order to keep the Illawarra steel industry viable.
“Today was a vote as to whether or not the steelworks stays open or whether it shuts,” Mr Phillips said.
“It requires courage for the result to go the way it did today.
“It’s a tough moment, no doubt, but I’m at least satisfied that workers have voted to fight another day.”
But Mr Phillips said NSW Premier Mike Baird should meet the union “half way” and agree to mandate the use of local steel for state government-funded projects.
BlueScope Steel warned in August that without $200 million in cuts, the Illawarra operation would have to shut.
Overtime payments will also be overhauled, with the agreement backdated to the start of July.
With Michael Roddan
